characters: .-.SHE IS SITTING A FOOT FROM HIS FACE, HER FACE A BLOODY
CURIOSITY AND MALICE, GRINNING AT HIM.
CAMERA PUSHES IN, ROTATING. WE HEAR THE GRIDLOCK OF THE
BLACK MESS OF ZOMBIE DISEASE, YELLOW EYES ALIVE WITH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAM! A GUY is sprinting like mad toward a high school football field. BOOM! A truly frightening, snarling male ZOMBIE is right on his heels, sprinting after him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rule #1 - Cardio.  Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: 1. Cardio

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pretty self-explanatory, um... do a lot of cardio. There'll be times when you have to run for your life. Literally. So get in shape. The GUY is still running, but every breath is now searing painful. His body is obviously SHUTTING DOWN on him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Zombies lead a very active lifestyle. The ZOMBIE, by contrast, is breathing nicely.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So should you. A wide master shot (a la a football broadcast) of the GUY running down the football field like a running back, and zombie, like a linebacker, DRAGGING him down from behind.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rule #2 - Zip-Loc Bags. A MAN sits alone in a school CAFETERIA at night, eating f a big jar of pickles. Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: 2. Zip-Loc Bags Suddenly, the fluorescent ceiling lights SHORT-CIRCUIT, SPARK, and go OUT, plunging the room into darkness. The m is illuminated only by a sliver of MOONLIGHT from a nearb WINDOW. The man stands up and pulls a FLASHLIGHT from his backpac

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Always pack wisely. This should go without saying, but you'd be surprised. I'm a big fan of Zip-Loc bags. You've got enough problems, moisture shouldn't be one of them. The man flicks the switch on the flashlight, but it doesn turn on. He empties the D-BATTERIES onto his palm to discover that they’ve CORRODED.  The man stares into the darkness with a concerned look, gathers his courage, then takes a step forward out of the moonbeam and into the dark... ...and is yanked the rest of the way and EVISCERATED.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rule #3 - Double Tap. A WOMAN stands on a city street, steely-eyed, resolute, holding a pistol with two hands. We hear rapid FOOTFALLS approaching her. Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: 3. Double Tap The footsteps belong to a big female ZOMBIE, who RUSHES straight AT the woman. The woman PLUGS the zombie in the chest with a bullet. The zombie FACE-PLANTS and lies motionless. Gun still raised, the woman approaches the zombie to test with her foot whether it’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You've just shot a zombie. You think it's dead, you're trying to save bullets... unh-uh. Two more shots. One to the head makes ninety-nine percent sure. One more to the head makes a hundred. It’s known as a Double Tap. The woman doesn’t follow Flagstaff’s advice. She NUDGES t zombie’s leg. It keeps its eyes CLOSED, like a little gir who's pretending to be asleep when her parents arrive hom after a night out.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's no use saving for the next zombie when this one's about to... The woman turns away, and the zombie slyly PEEKS at her. LUNGES and BITES VICIOUSLY into her ACHILLES TENDON.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ---give you a season-ending injury.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Rule #4 - Seatbelts. A panicky WOMAN turns the ignition in her CAR and SLAMS into gear. She does not, however, put on her SEATBELT. Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: 4. Seatbelts The woman swings her car in a wide arc, CLIPPING one ZOMB and narrowly avoiding ANOTHER.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look, I know you're in a rush. But it only takes two seconds. Call me a goody- two-shoes, but if you're in this much of a hurry, chances are you're about to get in a wreck. No sooner does Flagstaff say this than the woman pulls in front of an oncoming TRUCK. Her car is SMACKED in the sid The woman is THROWN through the side window of her car, a lands on the asphalt, deader than dead.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The pavement facial. Slightly worse than being a goody-two-shoes. Same ballpark. But slightly worse. EXT. GAS STATION - OUTSIDE MEN’S ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: OK, let's put these rules together. That guy there is me, probably about, what, a month after the zombie disease took off. I'm in West Covina, California. It may look like zombies destroyed it. Actually, that's just West Covina. FLAGSTAFF, a pale, unshaven, borderline good-looking NERD standing outside a gas station men’s room in West Covina, California, the arm-pit of the Golden State. Flagstaff holds a SHOTGUN. He’s trying to decide whether open the door. God knows what’s in there...

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I've just filled up at a strange gas station. I've gotta go number two. If caring too much about hygiene is an offense, then I'm a smooth criminal, I enjoy a clean place to go number two. I'm considering opening that bathroom door. Notice what a huge wuss I am.  Seriously, I don't have the guts God gave one of those trembly toy poodles, the kind that pees on eye contact. But I've survived so far, ‘cause I play it safe. Always by the rules. My rules... As Flagstaff navigates his way through the following acti scene, he follows ALL FOUR of rules #1-4. And what he jus said is the truth... we aren’t watching a hero here... ...we’re watching a COWARD. Flagstaff reaches for the bathroom DOOR, then stops, thin and decides AGAINST it. He backs away slowly, to discover made the RIGHT CALL: A male ZOMBIE BURSTS out the door, SCREECHING horribly. Flagstaff FLINCHES and fires the shotgun wildly, missing. Instead of fighting, he turns and RUNS. The ZOMBIE CHASES HIM, the end of a roll of TOILET PAPER stuck to its SHOE. The roll trails out behind as it runs. Flagstaff runs around the corner toward his SAAB, only to discover a FEMALE ZOMBIE in between him and the car. It SCREAMS and beelines for him. He FIRES at the new zombie but only hits it in the ARM. T shotgun pops open, its two chambers empty of shells. Rath than fight hand-to-hand, Flagstaff makes a wide-eyed DASH an adjoining dirt FIELD. We're with Flagstaff as he runs through the field, the tw zombies close behind. His lungs are in good shape. The zombies aren’t gaining. (The title: 1. Cardio reappears) A HIGH, WIDE SHOT reveals Flagstaff beginning to PULL AWA from the ZOMBIES as he leads them in a big circle back to the station and his car. Flagstaff runs up to the car, pulls out his KEYS, then spastically DROPS THEM as he’s going to put them in the l

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Shit! Flagstaff almost reaches down, but the zombies are catchi back up again. A wise decision: Flagstaff runs again for the FIELD. We're back watching the HIGH, WIDE SHOT. It’s comically exactly the same as the last one, with Flagstaff buying s time, pulling away from the ZOMBIES as he leads them in t big circle. (The title: 1. Cardio reappears, BLINKING ON

dialogues.speaker: AND OFF FOR EMPHASIS
dialogues.text: This time, Flagstaff reaches the car, successfully picks his keys, goes to put them in the lock, and then NOTICES the car wasn’t even locked anyway. He rolls his eyes, ope the door, JUMPS inside, closes the door, and SHOVES the k into the ignition, stopping only to... ...FASTEN his SEATBELT. Flagstaff FLOORS the car, FISHTAILING, putting distance between himself and the ZOMBIES, speeding down the street When all is clear, he takes a huge sigh of relief. The zombies give up the chase as Flagstaff’s Saab disappe

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And now, we're about to be reminded why I was such a moron for forgetting to lock my car... Flagstaff goes to adjust his REAR-VIEW MIRROR, and in it, sees a ZOMBIE SIT UP in the BACK SEAT, a big, bloody grin its face. Flagstaff SCREAMS, SLAMS on the brakes, swerves, and BASH into a SAGUARO CACTUS, which is decorating a man’s lawn. The ZOMBIE launches from the back seat of the car, SMASHE through the windshield, THUMPS its head against the cactu and ends up SPRAWLED on the hood. Flagstaff, by contrast, is SAVED by his SEATBELT, which T hard against his chest. (Title: 4. Seatbelts) Suddenly, the ZOMBIE, a PIECE of CACTUS stuck in its forehead, spins around on the hood and tries to get back through the hole in the cracked windshield. The WINDSHIELD WIPERS and WINDSHIELD CLEANING MIST are go off indiscriminately, spraying the zombie in the face and tapping it on the head. In the front seat, a terrified Flagstaff hurriedly pops o his SHOTGUN and grabs a ZIP-LOC BAG (Title: 2. Zip-Loc Ba off the floor next to him. It’s wet on the outside from t windshield fluid, but nice and DRY on the inside, and ful SHOTGUN SHELLS. Flagstaff loads a dry shell into his shotgun, aims, and SHOOTS the zombie off the hood of the car. Without pause, he pops the Shotgun open, loads TWO MORE SHELLS inside, climbs out, and STANDS OVER the fallen ZOM Flagstaff closes one eye and AIMS at the head. (Title: 3 Double Tap) KA-BLAM! KA-BLAM! Silence. Physically and emotionally spent, Flagstaff leans back against his car and SLIDES to the ground. He sniffs the a looks down, and gets a forlorn expression on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On the bright side, I'd found a place to go number two. FADE OUT. We hear the first notes of PATSY CLINE’S classic BALLAD, FALL TO PIECES.’

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP ON
dialogues.text: A MONTAGE of people succumbing to zombies as the world co to an end and the American Dream is lost...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN on a street scratches off a LOTTERY TICKET. He WHOO and JUMPS when he sees three CHERRIES. The man sprints inside a CONVENIENCE STORE with his ticke No one is behind the counter. He frowns and peers behind Without warning, a snarling ZOMBIE, dressed in a vest, JU UP from behind the counter and YANKS the man over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homemade BANNER over an idyllic children’s PARK reads, ‘FATHER SON SCOUT PICNIC!’ A FATHER and his eight-year-ol SON, dressed in SCOUT UNIFORMS, run awkwardly toward came Their LEGS are BOUND TOGETHER as part of a THREE-LEGGED R LURCHING after them are FOUR MORE FATHER-SON scout pairs, also tied at the leg, but foaming at the mouth. These fou pairs aren’t trying to beat the first place team, they’re trying to EAT the first place team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two young LOVERS at the MALL enter one of those gimmicky PHOTO booths, sit down, and pull the curtain. A HUNGRY ZOMBIE sneaks up, THROWS BACK THE CURTAIN, and DIVES INSI The booth SHAKES with the attack, then falls silent. A FOUR-PHOTO STRIP emerges into the pick-up slot. In the first photo, the couple is LAUGHING. In the second, they’re REACTING to the LUNGING zombie, i third they’re FIGHTING the zombie, and in the FOURTH, the bloody-mouthed zombie is looking happily into camera, as it remembers how to pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FAMILY of FOUR sits in a seat at the top of a FERRIS WH stranded by a clamoring CROWD of ZOMBIES below. They take each other’s hands and squeeze their palms tightly, forlo together. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flagstaff’s Saab is still bashed up against the cactus, S pouring from under its hood.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They say you can’t go home again. Me, I'm trying to prove ‘em wrong, making my way from my LA apartment to the only Place I've ever felt safe, Flagstaff, Arizona. On even the slightest chance Mom and Dad might still be alive. FLAGSTAFF himself has abandoned the car. He is walking up the street, everything but his shotgun stuffed into a ROL SUITCASE, which he tugs behind him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Moments like these made me glad... glad I chose that suitcase with the little rollers. I was done being the idiot with the duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF hikes up the on-ramp onto the freeway, shotgun under one arm, suitcase-on-wheels pulled behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF walks from abandoned VEHICLE to abandoned VEHIC looking carefully for a new ride. Nothing suits his purpo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An exhausted FLAGSTAFF trudges on, more slowly now. Then, if by magic, he hears the distant rumble of an ENGINE. On the western horizon, a black CADILLAC ESCALADE threads way through the abandoned freeway traffic, heading EAST. On each side and hood of the Escalade, written in WHITE S is the number 3 (in memory of the late great DALE EARNHAR As the ESCALADE approaches, a nervous FLAGSTAFF grabs a TOPPLED MOTORCYCLE, props it up on its kickstand, kneels behind it, and aims his shotgun warily at the nearing SUV The Escalade pulls up to within a few yards of the motorc and STOPS. The driver’s side door swings open, and a squa jawed, broad-shouldered bad ass, ALBUQUERQUE, steps onto running board. Albuquerque is in his mid-thirties. He wears ironic thick librarian-appropriate eyeglasses. He stares at the motorcycle with curiosity. Flagstaff stands up from behind the motorcycle with his shotgun AIMED at Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here's the thing about scared people. They're great at hiding it. Imagine an apple: nice and shiny on the outside, a greedy little worm chewing up the inside. That's me. Albuquerque raises an eyebrow, then shrugs matter-of-fact as if to say, ‘If that’s how you want to do it...’ Albuquerque calmly reaches into his car, pulls out a no- shitting-you AK-47 AUTOMATIC RIFLE, lifts it to his shoul and points it RIGHT BACK AT Flagstaff. Flagstaff’s eyes widen. Uh-oh. Albuquerque’s finger goes from the trigger guard to the TRIGGER. Flagstaff quickly wipes sweat from his temple with his sleeve, starts to tremble, then all at once GIVES UP, lowering his shotgun, setting it against the motorcycle, RAISING HIS HANDS, ashamed. Flagstaff smiles embarrassedly, then STICKS OUT ONE THUMB questioningly in the universal signal of HITCH-HIKING. Albuquerque rolls his eyes, lowers his gun, and motions t Flagstaff with his head: ‘Get in.’  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the SUV, ALBUQUERQUE sits behind the wheel. FLAGST sits in the passenger seat next to him. There’s an awkwar silence, punctuated by Flagstaff’s careful look OVER HIS SHOULDER INTO THE BACK SEAT.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Whatcha looking for?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Nothing. I have this list... Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: 31. Check the Back Seat

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: No one back there but my duffel bag. Flagstaff blinks.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Stop. No names. Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Arizona. Flagstaff.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Hullo, Flagstaff. I’m Albuquerque. The two SHAKE HANDS.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: You're from Albuquerque?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: You don’t want me to call you by your name? You want me to call you Albuquerque?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: May I ask why.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Keeps us from getting too familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So if I’m calling you Albuquerque, what happens if we meet someone else from Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Haven't thought that far ahead.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (smiles) If I knew I was gonna be Flagstaff, I'd have said I was from a cooler sounding place. Like, Pocatello. Or Winnemucca.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: You can switch to Winnemucca.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: No, I'm Flagstaff.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Sure?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (nods ) Flagstaff.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Flagstaff and Albuquerque almost had a gunfight.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Where you headed?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Flagstaff. You?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (nods knowingly) Going home?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Nah, home’s back there. (indicates West Covina) They say you know home by the way it makes you feel when you leave. I’m over it. Further I get, the better. 12.  13. (shrugs) Albuquerque’s just my birthplace. Not a destination. More like a... direction. Anywhere but here.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Y'know, Flagstaff’s on the way to Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: So... Albuquerque... wanna stick together? Least as far as Flagstaff?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Here’s the thing, Flagstaff. I’m not easy to get along with. And I’m sensing you're a bit of a bitch. I give this relationship until Quartzsite.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: So you'll take me as far as Quartzsite!

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: If you lose the excited face. Flagstaff loses the face. Albuquerque turns on the igniti

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I have a small bladder.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Clench and hold. The Escalade’s tires CRUNCH the gravel as it pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If I was stupid enough to hitch-hike, might as well have been with Albuquerque. Turns out... don't let the glasses fool you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SONG: RAGE AGAINST THE MACHINE’S ‘KNOW YOUR ENEMY.’ A hungry ZOMBIE SPRINTS toward an office building and DISAPPEARS around the corner. Suddenly, we hear a loud MECHANICAL BUZZING from around that corner.  14. After a beat, the SAME ZOMBIE comes SPRINTING back the wa came, with ALBUQUERQUE CHASING it from behind. At the moment, he is wearing a welder’s helmet and wielding two BUZZING CHAINSAWS, one in each hand. The zombie hightails it around a building. Albuquerque sl to a stop. He SNAPS his head back so that the shield of h welder’s mask lifts, and his FACE is fully revealed.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Albuquerque's in the ass-kicking business. And... Albuquerque SMIRKS.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (to the now-gone zombie) Business is good. The ‘Rage’ song fades.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don't get the wrong impression, Albuquerque's got a soft side. Look a month before the zombies showed up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALBUQUERQUE is in a modest KITCHEN, pre-Zombieland, cooki ANIMAL-SHAPED PANCAKES (pancakes with mouse ears, etc.) w a lot of tender loving care. Albuquerque spatulas the pancakes onto a PLATE and carries it to the kitchen table We REVERSE ANGLE to see the recipient of the pancakes: no child, but Albuquerque’s DOG, BUCK, a GERMAN SHEPHERD PUP Buck is sitting ON a chair at the table. Albuquerque WATC HAPPILY as Buck gobbles up the pancakes. Next, we see ALBUQUERQUE running in and out of frame, carrying Buck up in the air, zooming him around like an AIRPLANE, making machine-gunning and dive-bombing noises. At last, he falls to the ground with Buck and starts ESKI KISSING him (Buck licks him on the mouth) and blowing RASPBERRIES on his fuzzy BELLY.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's the grossest thing yet.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sign on the 10 freeway reads ‘QUARTZSITE - 89 MI.’ FLAGSTAFF and ALBUQUERQUE are driving down the freeway through a MOUNTAINOUS DESERT PASS when Albuquerque notice BROKEN GUARD RAIL and SLOWS to a STOP.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF and ALBUQUERQUE STANDING over the broken guard rail, each holding a SHOTGUN. There is an overturned HOST DELIVERY TRUCK at the bottom of a GORGE.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: That’s a Hostess truck.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: New plan. I could use a Twinkie. (laces up his boot) Coming? Flagstaff BLINKS. Does he really have to?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Hold on. Flagstaff starts doing some old-fashioned old-man TORSO TWISTS, ANKLE TOUCHES, and DEEP KNEE BENDS. He looks like one of those ridiculous yesteryear bodybuilders.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (watches ) You're serious.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Stretching’s important. You should stretch.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Don’t believe in it. Albuquerque starts down the gorge WITHOUT Flagstaff.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: You never see a lion stretch before it kills a gazelle! Flagstaff furrows his brow. An interesting point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF and ALBUQUERQUE carefully approach the overturn Hostess truck. The back delivery door is slightly AJAR.  16. Albuquerque and Flagstaff RAISE their GUNS. Flagstaff bit his lip. Albuquerque slowly REACHES for the door handle. Ominous violins swell...

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Whatever's inside an overturned Hostess truck, it can't be good for your health. All at once, Albuquerque THROWS BACK the door, and an AVALANCHE of BOXES of SNO-BALLS (those white, coconut-cov PUFFS) POURS out onto the ground. Nothing more dangerous than that. The music dies. Flagstaff SIGHS with relief. Albuquerque, however, isn’t nearly so happy: There’s not a TWINKIE in sight.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: What self-respecting Hostess truck is full of two thousand boxes of Sno-Balls?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I like Sno-Balls.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Coconut’s gross. Not the taste. The consistency. Flagstaff opens a package and starts CHOWING DOWN on a Sn Ball. A perturbed Albuquerque STARES. Flagstaff stops chewing and gives a guilty shrug, as if to say, ‘What?!’ Albuquerque heads back UP the steep slope.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: This Twinkie thing? Not over yet.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Um. This may be a bad time. But I gotta take the Browns to the Superbowl.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Really.  17. EXT. REST AREA - MEN’S ROOM - DAY The ESCALADE is parked outside a roadside REST AREA MEN’S ROOM, where ALBUQUERQUE stands, checking his watch. INT. MEN’S ROOM - DAY We're now inside the restroom. FLAGSTAFF has just entered holding his shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I know, I know... again so soon? What can I say? A case of chronic... anxiety. Ever since I was born, I've been ruled by irrational fears. Flagstaff nudges each stall door open with his foot, his nervousness plain to see.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's nothing I couldn't find a reason to be afraid of. Things like... Department Store Santas... quicksand... being held down and tickled... ANGLE ON: Flagstaff, now SITTING on one of the toilets.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For example, guess what I'm scared of right now. I mean, other than toilet seat herpes. Flagstaff pauses, then RAISES HIS FEET off the tile.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Something crawling under the stall! Flagstaff holds his feet up, keeping a sharp eye out for anything that might slither toward him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What crawls under a stall? I don’t know, a roach... a rat... a really thorough janitor? Use your imagination.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: An ALLIGATOR poking its head under the stall. Flagstaff BLINKS, and it DISAPPEARS.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I sure do.  18. EXT. REST AREA - MEN’S ROOM - DAY FLAGSTAFF emerges from the restroom to join ALBUQUERQUE.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (smiles) My work here is done. As Flagstaff and Albuquerque walk away, we hear a growing

dialogues.speaker: CACOPHONOUS SOUND
dialogues.text: TALKING, ETC.), and we SMASH CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nowadays, I'm always wishing life could go back to ‘normal.’ Which is weird. ‘Cause life was never really ‘normal’ for me. Long before there were ever zombies, phobias started boxing me in. I avoided more and more things. My world got smaller... We ZOOM IN instantly. The PHOTO is now only of one CITY, streets forming a grid. The traffic noise subsides a litt

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...and smaller... We ZOOM IN AGAIN. The PHOTO is now only of one NEIGHBORHO The traffic noise subsides again.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...and smaller. We ZOOM IN AGAIN. The PHOTO is now only of one APARTMENT BUILDING. The traffic noise is GONE. We’re in SILENCE. We push in on the roof, appearing to DISSOLVE THROUGH IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We push in on a bird’s eye view of FLAGSTAFF lying in bed curled up in the FETAL POSITION, his eyes WET with TEARS.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Til a few months back... when all that was left... was me. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: Then one Friday night... FLAGSTAFF is at his computer, lit by the pale glow of the screen, one hand under his waistband. His desk is a mess: Soda-can forest. Star Trek Voyager DVDs. Sticky keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Friday night, third straight week indoors. Leaning Tower of Pizza Boxes. Code Red Mountain Dew. Jessica Alba mouse pad. World of Warcraft. Right hand on Jessica. Left hand in pants. Pride - nowhere. Dignity - loooong gone. Virginity - totally justifiable to speculate on. His hands OCCUPIED, Flagstaff tries to take a DRINK from Code Red Mountain Dew cup by BITING the lip of it and TIP it back into his mouth. The Mountain Dew SPILLS all down chin and the front of his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Smooth. An annoyed Flagstaff marches into the bathroom, dripping Mountain Dew. He bends over the faucet and gets the shirt wet as can be to try to take out the stain. At last, he gives up, takes off the shirt, and DROPS it o the bathroom FLOOR. Flagstaff ducks into his closet to CHANGE shirts.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My whole life, all I'd ever really wanted was to find a girl. Fall in love. Bring her home to meet the folks. That was my biggest fear of all. Dying alone. Mom didn't know where I would meet a, quote, ‘marriageable woman,’ but Dad knew where I wouldn't: my locked apartment. And he'd always been right. ‘Til now... Just as Flagstaff is heading back to his computer, he hea POUNDING at his front door. He nearly jumps a foot in the air, then freezes, listening. The pounding stops for a second, then starts again, LOUDE Flagstaff TIPTOES down the hall and approaches his front as if it were the edge of the Grand Canyon.  20.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (muffled, distressed) 408, you in there?! Please! Flagstaff looks gingerly through the peep hole.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Omigod. My adorable next door neighbor. 406. I'd dreamed of this girl. But I'd never said hi, ‘cause I was busy making ground-breaking advances in the exciting new field of lame.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (now crying) Please, it’s an emergency! No one’s answering! Please?! Flagstaff is clearly TORN. He goes to open the door. Then CHICKENS OUT. Then listens to more resigned CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Heeeelp... Flagstaff finally can’t take it any more, his heartstring sufficiently tugged. He chokes down his fear and very daintily opens the latch and turns the KNOB. 406 BURSTS into the room, SLAMS the door behind her, bolt the latch, then HUGS Flagstaff like a long-lost relative. She is cuter than a button. Tough. Feisty. The kind of girl you'd love to spend Armageddon with. 406 (dispensing cheek pecks) Thank you, thank you, thank you! This showering of thanks can’t help but make Flagstaff fe good about himself. He puts on faux confidence:

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: It was nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF takes a seat beside 406 on his living room SOFA She wears a blanket over her shoulders. He offers her a c She thankfully takes it in both hands and DRINKS. 406 Mountain Dew?  21.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (nods ) Code Red. And some Golden Grahams. (hands her a plastic bag of Golden Grahams ) The Zip-Loc Bag keeps ‘em crisp. 406 Hm.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Why don’t you start from the beginning? 406 Not ‘til we’ve called the police.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Right, sorry! Flagstaff is already clutching CORDLESS PHONE. He hits th green ‘talk’ button. He doesn’t hear a dial tone. Instead it’s that fast ‘the phone’s been off the hook too long’ T 406 (hearing the tone) What’s wrong?! Mine was off, too. And I dropped my cell when... you got a cell?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (shakes his head... an embarrassing ‘no’) Probably the last guy in L.A. Wanna try down the hall? 406 In a bit. Right now I feel safe. Here.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Great. 406 He was homeless. And sick. I was walking home from a bar, talking on the phone. And this homeless guy came sprinting toward me. Not running. Sprinting. I thought he was, like, running after someone, or from someone, ‘til... ‘til... Her hands are shaking.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Here.  22. Flagstaff sets down her Mountain Dew and takes her hands BETWEEN his own, warming and stilling them. 406 (smiles through tears) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: OK, the confidence? Coming out of nowhere... seriously, maybe even my ass.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Go on. 406 He ran right for me. Just totally wild. Violent. He grabbed me. And I dropped my phone and pulled away. And ran. So did he. He must have slipped, ‘cause I made it inside the gate. Last I saw, he was still out there, going crazy.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Drugs, maybe? Bad trip? 406 I guess.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: He’1l just need time to come down. We’1l1 stay here ‘til the phones come back on. Then we’ll call the police. 406 I didn’t mention the worst part.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Yeah? 406 He tried to bite me. A BEAT while Flagstaff stares, grossed out.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: You're right. That’s the worst part. 406 Sorry I’m so scared.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Quit it! Some homeless guy tries to eat you?!  23. That's, like, the right kind of scared, reasonable scared. Me, I get scared of stuff like ventriloquist dummies, and those rags they use to wipe restaurant tables... 406 Really?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I joke a lot. The point is, I’m here for you. And as long as you’re by my side, I’m not leaving this apartment.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Playing to my strengths. 406 (sincere smile) Mind if I close my eyes? 406 KISSES Flagstaff on the forehead, then pulls the blan to her chin, leans back, and closes her eyes. Flagstaff c barely contain his jittery EXCITEMENT.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Set aside the feverish, homeless cannibal, I'm living the dream! I'd always... my whole life... wanted to brush a girl's hair over her ear. Flagstaff reaches out with his hand and brushes 406’s hai over her ear. She opens her eyes and smiles, then nestles back against the sofa cushion. 406 Night.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Night. Mountain Dew non-withstanding, sleepiness is contagious. Flagstaff watches 406 breathe peacefully for a few moment then props up a sofa pillow and closes his eyes HIMSELF. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF has been sound asleep for who knows how long. H sitting up on the couch, mouth open, head tilted to the l  24. We're on his FACE as he stirs. His eyelids flutter. He twitches, then opens his eyes, shaking off sleep. Where is he? Oh, right, on the couch. His kitchen is on t left. And 406 must still be on the couch. Flagstaff turns to the right, expecting to find 406 aslee next to him. Instead...

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Ghaaaaa! FLAGSTAFF leaps BACKWARD off the couch to get away from t ZOMBIEFIED 406.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Oh my God! Are you alright?! 406 stays where she is, SNIFFS the air longingly, and ope her mouth as if to say something. Instead, she HISSES/HOC UP PHLEGM, and then SPRINGS at Flagstaff with ABANDON.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Abhh! Flagstaff backs up as fast as humanly possible, then turn run. He SPRINTS MADLY into his tiny dining room with 406 right on his heels. Flagstaff overturns two DINING CHAIRS behind him to try to slow 406. She gets TANGLED and SLIPS 406 gets to her feet and lurches into the KITCHEN. Flagst has turned to face her, holding a BLENDER over his head.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Stay back! I don’t wanna hurt you! Zombies don’t generally stay back. She BUM-RUSHES him. Still wigged out by the idea of injuring his neighbor (however zombie-ish), Flagstaff DITCHES the blender and R 406 is right behind him when he reaches the BEDROOM and t to SLAM the door SHUT. She STICKS OUT her foot as if she’ about to slide into third base and tries to STOP it. The door SMASHES 406’s ANKLE, bending her foot SIDEWAYS w a sickening CRACK. She falls to the ground, screaming, in daze, clutching her now diagonally attached foot.  25.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Shit! Sorry! But nice as he may be, Flagstaff doesn’t waste a moment; tries to SLAM the door shut again. 406 LUNGES and gets he ARMS and SHOULDERS through. This time, the door has no chance whatsoever of closing. broken ankle has HOBBLED her, but she’s still coming... Flagstaff can’t retreat anywhere but the closet or the bathroom. He chooses the BATHROOM, dashing, reaching it. Unfortunately, he SLIPS on the WET, MOUNTAIN-DEW-COVERED SHIRT from earlier. He CRASHES to the TILE FLOOR, pulling the SHOWER CURTAIN out of its rings to try to break his f Now she’s reached his feet, biting, clawing. He KICKS frantically and haphazardly, but she’s got him by the ank He opens the CABINET under the sink for a weapon... Kleenex? No. Cotton Balls? No. Toilet Paper? Not happening. Flagstaff rolls his eyes. His arsenal is exclusively soft and fluffy. 406 rises up to jump on Flagstaff, and he just manages to pull the SHOWER CURTAIN over himself. She lands on top of him, and now THEY’RE WRESTLING, GRABBING, PUNCHING, with the CURTAIN in between them. Flagstaff falls back to the tile, WHACKING his HEAD. Now and the zombie are literally FACE to FACE, as if kissing, with the shower curtain still BETWEEN them. 406’s bloody features PRESS gruesomely against the PLASTI Flagstaff uses the moment to reach up and WRAP the curtai around the back of her head, trying to cut off her AIR. It’s WORKING... she gasps, wheezes, chokes, and at last starts to go LIMP. We think it’s about to be OVER... ..-until she CHEWS through the plastic, which allows her take a DEEP, raspy BREATH. Her gangrenous tongue PROTRUDE through the hole, ALMOST LICKING Flagstaff on the mouth.. Flagstaff GROPES in the cabinet under the sink again, gra an aeresol can of LYSOL, AIMS it into her mouth, and FIRE 406 CHOKES and rolls off Flagstaff. He gains his feet, SL back against the TOILET, and knocks the PORCELAIN LID on back of the toilet basin ASKEW.  26. This gives him an idea. He grabs the heavy LID and steps over 406, SWATTING her hand with it as he runs from the r Flagstaff SHUTS the bathroom door behind him, and the bed door behind him after that. Unfortunately, he’s on the wr side of the locks now, so he can’t lock her out of anywhe We're now with 406 as she rises to her feet again. She instinctively tries to BEND her broken foot back into pla CRACKING it from one odd angle to another. No luck, now i just as twisted, only in the other direction. 406 gives up on her foot and opens the bathroom door. The she limps to the bedroom door and opens it, too. Flagstaf is standing in the living room, chest heaving.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Please listen to me, 406. Listen. If you're in there. You’re just sick. Stop. Don’t... But 406’s expression is one of pure, blinded hate. She throws back her head and HOWLS with rage. The sound is beyond scary, like that of a trapped, infuriated animal. And she RUN-DRAGS herself TOWARD him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Forgive me. With all his might, he rears back and BELTS her in the he with the TOILET BASIN LID. At the EXACT MOMENT of jarring IMPACT, we FREEZE FRAME. We see a STILL SHOT of Flagstaff connecting perfectly, violently with 406’s temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WATER. Running from the faucet... eddying in the sink wit blood and grime... splashing on walls and mirror.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You tell yourself over and over, this... this... did not just happen. It did not. It did not. It did not. It couldn't have. It couldn't have.  27. INTERCUT, we see QUICK IMAGES of FLAGSTAFF’s pain, fear, grief: He’s washing his hands feverishly in the sink. He’ nearly HYPERVENTILATING. He’s spasming in a near FIT of panting and groans. He’s sitting still against his bathroom wall and TREMBLIN

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But it did. In the face of every sane thing that came before it, and all I'd come to know and expect about the world... it did.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF, with a phone to his ear, still hearing the not service TONE. He sets down the receiver. In tears, he carries his SHOWER CURTAIN into the living room. He stands over 406’s dead body, chokes back the smell, th starts to wrap her in the SHOWER CURTAIN, DUCT-TAPING the edges. As he goes to move her arm, something makes him st

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A ‘zombie’ isn't a dead person who's come back to life. It’s someone who's been infected with the plague of the 21st century - a terrible disease that leaves its victims irrationally violent and hateful, some insist evil. JZombieism is carried in bodily fluid. Near 406’s wrist is a severe BITE MARK that bears the unmistakable imprint of human teeth. Flagstaff examines t bite mark, his mind racing with the implications.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: These fluids are highly contagious and fast-acting when they mix with your fluids. So if you're thinking of going tongue-to-tonsil with your suddenly less- cute neighbor... A QUICK CUT of 406 trying to stick her TONGUE into Flagstaff’s mouth through the shower curtain.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...try something more innocent. Flagstaff sadly BRUSHES 406’s HAIR over her EAR, then RES wrapping her up.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From across the street, we watch in a MASTER SHOT as FLAGSTAFF struggles to push 406’s shrouded CORPSE over hi apartment balcony. We're BELOW the balcony, looking UP as the wrapped body r over and PLUMMETS INTO LENS. ALL IS BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mom and Dad would have to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALBUQUERQUE and FLAGSTAFF have resumed driving down the freeway. Flagstaff is staring at DEAD, CHARRED DRIVERS in BURNED VEHICLES.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I’ve heard there’s still a place untouched by all this crap.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Back east, right?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: You heard the same thing?!

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Sure. Out west, we’ve heard it’s back east. Back east, they’ve heard it’s out west. There’s no such place. Get over it. You're like the penguin at the north pole who’s heard the south pole’s really nice this time of year.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: There are no penguins at the north pole. A moment passes. Albuquerque ponders.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Wanna see how hard I can punch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALBUQUERQUE and FLAGSTAFF are driving through a new secti of the 10 FREEWAY, weaving through abandoned cars, in MID CONVERSATION.  29.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: The last time I ‘laid some pipe?’

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Yeah. The last time you went twenty toes... put Percy in the playpen... stormed the trenches... Flagstaff stares.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Sex?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Sex. Flagstaff’s eyes drift to a BILLBOARD for UPS. He begins tentative lie that gets more confident with every word:

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Three weeks ago. The back of an abandoned UPS truck.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Shut. Up.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I was headed east. She was headed west. We took shelter in the truck. Full of undelivered packages. High-powered binoculars. Case of apple butter. Phone shaped like a football. We started to open ‘em up. And... y’know... work ‘em in.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: What was her name?!

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Beverly. (smiles) Hills.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: You dog.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He's dumber than I thought.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: How ‘bout you?  30.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Me? I... I... (sees trouble ahead, grimaces) ..-Aye-yay-yay... Albuquerque STOPS the ESCALADE. A female ZOMBIE is on the road ahead, perched over a dead BUSINESSMAN, eating him.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Oh, God. The zombie holds up the businessman’s THIGH BONE, chewing it like a piece of corn-on-the-cob, so intent on the meal that it doesn’t notice Flagstaff and Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: It makes you...

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I know, it makes you sick. It makes you... (bows his head, then raises it) ...Sad. About... I don’t know, the way things were. It makes you think, if you could go back in time, right now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're watching a HOME VIDEO of FLAGSTAFF as an eight-year KID. A nerd-in-waiting. With his loving PARENTS.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ---you'd be eating Mom's tuna surprise... or playing Ants in the Pants with Dad... not knowing how things would end up. It makes you think your home is so close you could touch it. But so far away. And instead, this... this... (can't think of the word)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The zombie BREAKS the bone in TWO and SUCKS OUT the MARRO

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: ..-this. It makes you... sad. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna say it makes you hungry. That’s exactly how I eat a Twinkie. Break it open and eat the inside out. We need to find some. Fast. A long pause. Flagstaff stares at Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I’m worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: You’re the one playing Ants in the Pants with Dad. Look, I hate to poop on the parade, but whatever’s waiting for you in Flagstaff, it ain’t any prettier than our friend eating her manwich here. Best do like me and put home sweet home in your rear view. (raises his arm) Hold on... ALBUQUERQUE reaches UP and hits the ON-STAR button (GM's roadside assistance service). After two rings, a young AFRICAN-AMERICAN WOMAN'S VOICE comes over the car SPEAKER

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On-Star. How can I help you? Flagstaff is SHOCKED to hear a voice on the line.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Detroit! It’s Albuquerque!

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Albuquerque! You don’t call, you don’t write! How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Better now, Beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Quit.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Detroit, say hello to my new best friend: Flagstaff.

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Flagstaff, I’m so sorry for you.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: On-Star still works?! 31.  CLICK. 32.

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I’m the last one here. But the system’s still up. And I’m not ready for retirement.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Detroit was just another On-Star operator. Now she’s the Guardian Angel of Zombieland. Our eye in the sky...

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: How can I help?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: We're looking for the nearest grocery store...

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT
dialogues.text: Grocery? Let’s see. Little town of Leland. Sixteen miles, second light, take a right. Good luck. God bless. (a pause) And thank you for using On-Star...

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Does she sound hot to you?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: People in the telecommunications industry usually are.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: She’s got a sister... The Escalade ACCELERATES. Flagstaff looks forlornly OVER SHOULDER. The ZOMBIE and the CORPSE FADE into the DISTANCE. Flagstaff has that three-mile stare.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It does make you wonder. What it is about me and Albuquerque that we're still around to make grocery lists, while those two souls ended up on either end of a mid- afternoon snack? You never know...

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: For instance, here's a little drinking game: Take a look at the following pre- Zombieland scene and try to predict who's gonna survive post-Zombieland... We're outside a PRE-ZOMBIELAND gas station, on the outski of a busy city. Hustle. Bustle. Cars whizzing by. Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: One month earlier We crane all the way to the ASPHALT, where a well-dressed put-upon young WOMAN, mid-twenties, is kneeling down, frantically searching on the ground next to some gas pump The woman is GORGEOUS, but an emotional wreck. Her search totally FRUITLESS, and she fights back tears. The MANAGER of the gas station, a shifty-eyed GREASE-BALL sees her and comes out to help.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Whatcha looking for?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: My engagement ring. I took it off to pump my gas. Thought I put it in my purse, but it must have...

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (peeks around) What’s it look like?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Big and... (starts to cry) ...-beautiful. (re: crying) Sorry. It’s just, what will I tell my fiance? And I’m late for my flight.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (sly) Tell you what. Gas is on me. Gimme your number. You get on that flight. I’m gonna turn this place upside down. I’11l find your ring. Send it Fed-Ex. Your fiance will never know.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’1l give you a reward.  34.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Three thousand dollars. (off the manager's raised eyebrow, sotto voce) You don’t understand. It’s worth more than my car. The manager steals a furtive glance at the woman’s car: a cute RED BMW CONVERTIBLE. He deftly conceals his exciteme

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (smiles) I’m not taking your three thousand dollars. But I will take your number. The woman’s face says it all: Can she trust him? At last:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you so much... She gives him her card.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THE BMW PULLING AWAY... The MANAGER waves, watching the c disappear, then TURNS QUICKLY and SCOURS THE PAVEMENT.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: LATER... The MANAGER is sweaty with the effort of searchi He’s sorting the TRASH. Nothing. A PHONE RINGS inside. He tosses aside a gross BANANA PEEL and jogs into his OFFICE

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: A BIT LATER... The MANAGER is still on the phone in the office, his back turned to the window.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (into phone) I told you, she’s on a plane! That’s the beauty of it! He turns around and SPIES an ELEVEN-YEAR-OLD GIRL bending over something SHINY on the sidewalk. The girl is sharp, tomboyish, wise beyond her years, hair tousled, a quick study.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Crap!  35. Like LIGHTNING, the manager HANGS up and SPRINTS OUTSIDE. The girl is standing up, examining a HUGE, SPARKLING RING

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: You found my ring! The girl looks up. The manager reaches out with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Thank you. I’ve been looking all over for it. The girl looks WARY. She speaks with a SOUTHERN ACCENT:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Your ring?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (thinks ) Not exactly mine. A friend of mine’s. A nice lady. She was sad to lose it. I’m gonna send it to her.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Look, here’s her phone number! The manager produces the woman’s CARD. A long pause while the girl considers it.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: That could be anyone’s number.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Look, kid, I’m not making this up. The lady’s getting married. She needs her ring. But the girl is still RELUCTANT.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Santa Claus is watching...

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Do I get a reward?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: There’s candy in the office.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.  36. He turns to LEAVE.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (panic setting in) You can’t sell it, if that’s what you’re thinking. A kid like you takes that ring into a store, they’re only gonna ask a bunch of questions. Besides, a big store, it’s not worth anything to them. The girl turns back.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: It is to you. The manager stares daggers into the kid. He’s at the END his ROPE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MANAGER is standing at the CASH REGISTER, COUNTING OF TWENTY dollar BILLS into the GIRL’s HAND.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Forty, sixty, eighty... four hundred. That’s four hundred dollars. The whole register. He tilts the register tray toward the girl to show her th it’s empty. The girl TILTS the tray in the OTHER DIRECTIO revealing another stack of TWENTIES UNDER THE TRAY. The manager sags, scoops them up, and hands them over.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: OK, five hundred more. For a total of nine.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: And the candy.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: (gaze narrows) One bar. The girl grabs an Aba Zabba. Then she takes a good, hard look at the RING. The manager was pretty quick to hand ou that nine hundred dollars. Nevertheless, a deal’s a deal. The girl HANDS OVER the ring.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: You’ve made someone very happy.  37. The girl marches out of the office with her cash and her half-eaten Aba Zabba.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (mouth full) You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GIRL walks AROUND THE CORNER, to where the GAS STATIO no longer in sight. She walks up to a car parked in the shade of a tree. It’s the SHINY RED BMW CONVERTIBLE. The girl climbs into the passenger seat and shuts the door. The beautiful WOMAN smirks at her from the driver’s seat.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (forks over the cash) Seven hundred.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Uh, uh, uh... The girl produces five more twenties.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: OK, eight. The woman smiles and KISSES her on the forehead lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I’m guessing at least nine. But keep the difference. You earned it. How many left? The girl opens the GLOVE COMPARTMENT, takes out a manila ENVELOPE, and dumps fifteen fat identical costume engagem RINGS into her LAP. She holds one up to the light.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Someday, I want a ring this big.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: For the low price of thirty bucks, sold.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (offers her candy) Aba Zabba?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Nine grams Trans Fat. Seatbelt. The girl puts on her SEATBELT and pulls out a ROAD MAP of UNITED STATES.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: California’s far.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Exactly. The woman lowers the TOP of the CONVERTIBLE. We CRANE UP the two DRIVE AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN and the GIRL speed down the freeway in the red The girl has the window down and her arm out the window. With her hand, she adjusts the SIDE VIEW MIRROR. She creaks the mirror out a bit. Then creaks it back in. Then OUT AGAIN. All the while, her EYES remain fixated on what she can see in the mirror. The woman NOTICES.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Stop looking.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (nonchalant) What?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: He’s not following us.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I know, just making sure. (off the woman’s intense look, covering: ) About the gas station guy! The woman’s not buying it. The girl insists:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I think he was onto us! The woman has heard enough.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Listen. Dad’s not following us. He’s not. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Say it: He’s not following us.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: He’s not following us.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Good. You and I are safe. I promise. Dad won’t find us. Ever. He’s smart. He sucks. But he’s not, like, God. We're going all the way to California. And how many people will live in California by the year 2009?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Thirty-nine million.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Thirty-nine million..?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: (smiles) .--and two.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Besides. Remember. Nothing bad ever happens at Disneyland.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Promise?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (nods ) It’s the happiest. Place. The woman puts out her fist. The girl looks at it, then SMIRKS and gives her a Tiger-Woods-style FIST POUND.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: On earth. The car finds a lower gear and ACCELERATES away. INT. GAS STATION MEN’S ROOM - DAY

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Fast forward to Zombieland. Any guesses who's gonna survive? If you said this guy... take a drink... 39.  40. The MANAGER is sitting in a stall on the TOILET. He hears the main DOOR to the bathroom swing OPEN.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Can a guy take a growler in peace?! The manager GASPS. A ZOMBIE has poked its HEAD under the stall door, and is STARING at him with a RAVENOUS SMILE. The manager SCREAMS, and the stall SHUDDERS with the viol of the attack.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: See?! Crawling under the stall! Crawling under the stall! FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: Leland, Arizona Another TITLE: Ralph’s Grocery

dialogues.speaker: FADE UP ON
dialogues.text: The ESCALADE, parked by a GROCERY STORE in the desert tow Leland. Another TITLE: Double Coupon Sunday FLAGSTAFF and ALBUQUERQUE are standing by the open tailga of the Escalade, where Albuquerque gathers some EQUIPMENT He grabs a pair of wicked-looking HEDGE CLIPPERS. He snag an aluminum BASEBALL BAT and slides two DOUGHNUT SHAPED WEIGHTS onto the end. And he takes out an ACOUSTIC GUITAR and slides it over his shoulder by the strap. Flagstaff watches, bemused, then looks up at the store.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I used to love grocery shopping.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: No one loved grocery shopping. Albuquerque SLAMS the tailgate SHUT with a flourish and Marches toward the front doors, Flagstaff in tow.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: The whole ‘zombies only eat human flesh’ thing? Total myth.  41. They’1l eat anything. I know ‘cause I’ve seen ‘em eat tofu, black licorice, and fourteen of the fifteen offerings from Lean Cuisine. Albuquerque steps on the door pad, and the doors slide op

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Which one won't they touch? A bit of a head scratcher: Teriyaki Chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're now inside the grocery store, where ALBUQUERQUE str toward the aisles. FLAGSTAFF slinks behind, holding his SHOTGUN. The place is a MESS, food strewn everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When Albuquerque goes Hulk on a zombie, he sets the standard for not-to-be-fucked- with. Intensely violent. Creatively violent. No fear. Like he’s got nothing to lose. I wish I didn’t feel such a rush watching it, but what can I say? It's like... art. As if on cue, a hugely OBESE ZOMBIE jumps out from behind counter. Albuquerque unslings the GUITAR, spins, and BRAI the zombie with it. Then Albuquerque makes like a member of The Clash, RAISIN the guitar over his head and bringing it down on the zomb again and again. Suddenly, a second MORBIDLY OBESE ZOMBIE rushes on. This time, Albuquerque readies the baseball bat with the dough weights. He cocks and swings like Alex Rodriguez, CRUSHIN its head into a display of snacks. At last, one final FAT ZOMBIE waddles toward Albuquerque. faces it with a smile, holding up the big HEDGE CLIPPERS. SNAPS them a couple times. The zombie PAUSES, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: The NOW-BLOODY HEDGE CLIPPERS sliding across the floor, tossed aside. FLAGSTAFF’s mouth is open. He’s half amazed half nauseated. Albuquerque looks at the three HUGELY FAT DEAD ZOMBIES.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: These three really let themselves go.  42.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Being a zombie is depressing. And what cures depression? Dessert food. Albuquerque’s EYES WIDEN as he considers this. All at onc he DASHES into the DESSERT FOOD AISLE. A couple beats. Albuquerque walks out slowly, angrily, discarding a couple EMPTY TWINKIE BOXES. To add insult to injury, he strolls into the FREEZER AISLE, looks, then pl out a PACKAGE. He walks over and hands it to FLAGSTAFF: A PRISTINE BOX of Lean Cusine’s TERIYAKI CHICKEN.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (sighs) Got a quarter? I wanna ride the rocket ship.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Which leaves me the pony! Albuquerque is nearly out the door when he suddenly STOPS He motions for Flagstaff to be still.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Hear that? We hear the sound of MOVEMENT in an aisle. Flagstaff RAIS his SHOTGUN. Slowly, Albuquerque and Flagstaff inch aroun the corner of the aisle to see what’s making the noise. STANDING in the aisle is the WOMAN of FLAGSTAFF’s DREAMS, twenty-something, bedraggled, but naturally GORGEOUS, who also just happens to be... ...THE CON-WOMAN FROM THE RED BMW.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: All I could think, all I could think, was what are the odds: another ‘marriageable woman’ to bring home to the folks. Zombieland's like eharmony, only fewer gruesome surprises! Someone's ear’s in danger of having hair brushed over it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Flagstaff’s excited, expectant expression fades as th woman’s face contorts into ANGUISH and TERROR.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Come quick...  43. The woman turns toward the back of the store. Albuquerque and Flagstaff share an anxious look.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Guard the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF is planted outside the store, standing guard, nervously shifting his weight from foot to foot.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Flagstaff!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALBUQUERQUE has FLAGSTAFF by the arm, leading him to the of the store.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (voice lowered) They’re sisters. The young one’s been bitten. Act normal. Don’t freak her out... Albuquerque throws open the doors to the BUTCHER SHOP.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Flagstaff... Meet Wichita... and Stillwater. WICHITA is the woman from the red BMW. And yes, STILLWATE is her ll-year-old sister. Zombieland has clearly taken i toll on these two, but they’re still alive, which is all counts. Stillwater sits languidly against a counter. She looks pa sweaty. Flagstaff shakes Wichita’s hand, then Stillwater’ As he shakes with Stillwater, his eyes dart to a bloody, mouth-shaped WOUND on her WRIST. Stillwater closes, then OPENS her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: You did all this... for a Twinkie?

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: He did, actually. I’m more of a... second banana. Wichita pulls Albuquerque and Flagstaff aside. The three talk in hushed tones.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: She doesn’t have long.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: I know. (gathers her composure) And she knows. We’re just looking for a way out. Wichita’s eyes go to Flagstaff’s SHOTGUN. Flagstaff’s follows her gaze, then SHAKES his HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Oh no you don’t. She’s just a girl.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: Don’t talk about me like I’m not here!

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (crosses to Stillwater) I know you’re sick, but, she wants me to...

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: It’s not her decision. It’s mine. I made her promise. I made her promise. We already said goodbye. But we didn’t have a gun.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: This may sound crazy, but we’re still not sure there’s no cure! You never know...

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: You’re just gutless. Give him the gun. She motions toward ALBUQUERQUE, who’s currently lost in t ethical dilemma of the moment. But he hears Stillwater’s wish. After a few beats, he strides over and GRABS HOLD o the shotgun. Flagstaff RESISTS, but he YANKS it away. Flagstaff turns his back, DISGUSTED, as Albuquerque steps tentatively toward Stillwater. Wichita bites her lip.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: Wait. Wichita holds out her hand.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: I’1l do it.  45. Albuquerque hesitates, then HANDS the SHOTGUN to Wichita. She musters her poise and walks over to her sister. Stillwater and Wichita share a poignant glance, then take each other’s hand. Wichita squeezes Stillwater’s palm. Sh checks the gun for shells (they’re there), then closes it

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Is there anything we can do?

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: Since you mention it... Wichita turns the SHOTGUN AWAY from Stillwater and POINTS RIGHT AT Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: ...we’ll take your car keys, weapons, ammunition... Stillwater POPS OFF the floor with a burst of energy and SMIRK.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: .--and if you’ve got it, sugarless gum. Flagstaff turns around. What the hell?! Albuquerque swallows his surprise. He points to Stillwater’s ‘bite’:

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: (As in, ‘You're such a dummy... anyone in there?’) Hello? (gestures to the room in which they’re standing) Butcher shop. Stillwater RUBS OFF the COW BLOOD. There’s no wound at al Flagstaff looks stunned.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Why would you do this?

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: (taking ammo from Flagstaff) Better you make the mistake of trusting us. Than us make the mistake of trusting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my folks would've been so pleased.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: I could not be more bummed.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: Life’s a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Look. Who’s. Talking. Wichita SNATCHES Albuquerque's keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WICHITA drives Albuquerque’s ESCALADE west down the freew STILLWATER sits in the passenger seat. Wichita flips down the visor and looks in the vanity mirr She WINCES at her close-up appearance, immediately flippi the visor back up.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: Avoid the vanity mirror.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: Relax. I just passed for a zombie! Stillwater flips down her own mirror and frowns.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: I’m having a bad hair month.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: (smiles) If there were an Olympics for greasy? (points to Stillwater) Gold. Stillwater smiles, too. But the smile fades. Wichita trie to drum up a little spirit:

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: Remind me what we heard about the Magic Kingdom.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: Zombie-free.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: Good enough for me... 46.  47. Wichita plants the accelerator on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALBUQUERQUE and FLAGSTAFF are trolling through Leland, looking for a replacement for the ESCALADE. Flagstaff is carrying Albuquerque’s DUFFEL BAG ON TOP of his ROLLING SUITCASE like a Sherpa.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: What I’m gonna miss most?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Sure? Albuquerque STARES impatiently at Flagstaff.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: The twenty-inch wheels. Followed by the bucket seats. With the lumbar. (looks at Albuquerque) And the rich... premium... audio. Is this really helping?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Do what you want to a guy. But do not fuck with his Cadillac.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (points) There’s a nice minivan.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (brightens) Yeah, nice! Albuquerque approaches the MINIVAN in question, pauses fo effect, and then KICKS the LIVING SHIT out of it. SMASHES the door panel. RIPS off the side-view mirror. JUMPS up a down on the HOOD. Then falls right back INTO STEP with Flagstaff, who has kept on walking. A few beats pass. Then:

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: I pulled something.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Stretch...  48.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Are the two of us smart enough to come up with a con like that? Flagstaff eyes Albuquerque and HESITATES.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Oh, man. You hesitated. (SEES something in the DISTANCE, pauses) Question: Is it better to be smart? Or... lucky? Albuquerque breaks into a SPRINT. Flagstaff FOLLOWS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF finishes his jog, where he finds ALBUQUERQUE already circling his new DISCOVERY... ..-a brand spanking new HUMMER H2, in BLACK, parked askew some guy’s driveway, smacked into a wooden garage support Albuquerque throws open the driver’s door and finds a KEY the ignition. He turns it, and the Hummer ROARS to LIFE. Albuquerque CACKLES. Flagstaff opens the passenger door a dutifully, cautiously peers into the BACK SEAT. Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: 31. Check the Back Seat Sitting on the back seat is a BIG paramilitary-style CANV BAG. Flagstaff examines the bag: You don’t think..? He looks up at the house, which has a Confederate flag flyin Flagstaff slowly pulls back the zipper to discover an ARR of WICKED-LOOKING PARAMILITARY WEAPONRY. Flagstaff gently CLEARS his THROAT to get Albuquerque’s attention. Albuquerque turns and looks into the bag.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: No. Way. Twin .50 Caliber DESERT EAGLE PISTOLS. Two COMBAT SHOTGUN BOXES of AMMUNITION. And the crowning glory... an absolut pristine, deadly, monstrous STEYR AUG AUTOMATIC RIFLE. Albuquerque is a twelve-year-old boy again:

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: This is a really big truck. (deep breath) And these are really big guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flagstaff claps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF sits patiently in the passenger seat of the Hum YAWNING. Visible behind Flagstaff in the rear window (out focus due to the long lens, and muffled because he’s outs the closed truck) is ALBUQUERQUE, who fires a BURST with automatic rifle to test it, then starts whooping like an idiot, dancing, and punching the air in CELEBRATION (insp by a famous shot from ‘Ferris Bueller's Day Off’). At last, Albuquerque opens the driver’s door and HOPS in.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: Done?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Maayybe. Albuquerque FLOORS the Hummer, splintering the rest of th garage support and bouncing onto the street. EXT./INT. 10 FREEWAY/HUMMER -— DAY The HUMMER heads down the freeway, ALBUQUERQUE and FLAGST in the front seats.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: You're scary happy.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: You get sentimental, you talk about home. For me, home was a dog named Buck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In flashback, the PRE-ZOMBIELAND ALBUQUERQUE is giving hi German Shepherd puppy BUCK a BATH. Albuquerque shapes the fur on Buck’s head into a MOHAWK and laughs at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the Hummer, ALBUQUERQUE continues his story.  50.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: There’s no getting him back. So I’m looking for a new home. And by home I don’t mean Mom’s tuna surprise, or some bullshit place with no zombies. I mean something... anything... that makes me feel one one-thousandth of the way I did around Buck. Tomorrow, maybe that’s skinny-dipping in the Yellowstone River... the next day, maybe swinging from the chandeliers in the Lincoln Bedroom. But today? A Vortec 6 liter V- 8. A boxful of .50 cal. And lord willing, a G.D. twinkie. Gotta enjoy the little things... Albuquerque turns on the CD player. A SONG begins: BILLY JOEL’S ‘KEEPING THE FAITH.’ There is no better music for feeling good when you should otherwise be feeling bad. Albuquerque sticks his HEAD out the SUN ROOF, singing int the wind:

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Gonna listen to my forty-fives! Ain’t it wonderful to be alive, when the rock-n- roll plays! Albuquerque inadvertently catches a BUG in the MOUTH. He HACKS. Flagstaff pulls out a tiny NOTEBOOK and WRITES in

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I hate to give credit to anyone who eats bugs. But I'm even writing it down. Rule #32 For Surviving Zombieland - Enjoy the Little Things. Albuquerque considers something, momentarily lowers the volume on the stereo, and hits the ON-STAR BUTTON.

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On-Star. How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Detroit, Albuquerque.

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Handsome!

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: We need another grocery store. And before I forget, we found a new ride.  51.

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A Hummer! You stud. I’m so relieved! After what happened to the Caddy... Albuquerque starts to nod, then STOPS with a FROWN.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: You know what happened to the Escalade?

dialogues.speaker: DETROIT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Just it’s been dead for an hour. Mile marker two-ten. ‘Check Engine’ light on. I was worried. But you found a new ride. So it’s all good. Albuquerque and Flagstaff share a look.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: It’s alllll good. Albuquerque hits the GAS. He is practically salivating. T Hummer turns onto the 10 FREEWAY, headed WEST. FLAGSTAFF fidgets in his seat UNCOMFORTABLY.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: They say ‘He who seeks revenge should remember to dig two graves...’

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Right. Two graves. One for the big chick. And one for the little chick. Albuquerque turns the volume back up, and ‘KEEPING THE FA resumes at FULL BLAST.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘KEEPING THE FAITH’ keeps playing as the HUMMER ZOOMS dow the 10 FREEWAY... through a FOREST OF JOSHUA TREES... und a BLOOD-RED SUN... A gorgeous HAWK flies overhead. FLAGSTAFF can’t help but admire the fiery landscape. Superimposed onscreen: A TITLE: 32. Enjoy the Little Things

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SUN is LOW in the sky over the Arizona desert. The Hummer is parked at the top of a valley, about a mile acr high on one side, high on the other, depressed in the mid The freeway runs right down to the valley floor and up th other side. And at the exact bottom sits Albuquerque's ESCALADE, its hood popped. ALBUQUERQUE watches through HI POWERED BINOCULARS. FLAGSTAFF looks on. Three letters have been added to Albuquerque’s big number on the side of the SUV. It now reads, ‘H3LP’ (HELP). There looks to be MOVEMENT UNDER THE HOOD, as evidenced b some moving CLOTH and a SHADOW on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (grabs his STEYR AUG rifle) Knowing them? It’s a trap. Stay here. Drive down if I signal.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: You’re not gonna shoot them?

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Not unless they shoot at me. (slaps a clip into the Steyr Aug) Let’s hope they shoot at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALBUQUERQUE walks toward the Escalade in the smartest, stealthiest way possible, using all available cover, STEY AUG RAISED. He looks UNDER the truck. No one there. He throws open the tailgate. No one there. At last, he peers around the hood. A BLOUSE is hanging from the raised hood ornament on a HANGER, ostensibly to provide SHADE for whoever was worki under the hood. That’s what was causing the moving SHADOW Albuquerque steps carefully away from the Escalade until safely fifty yards off, surrounded by flat, empty desert. Then he SIGNALS FLAGSTAFF to drive down.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: FLAGSTAFF pulling up to ALBUQUERQUE in the HUMMER. Albuquerque clambers into the PASSENGER SEAT.  53.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: They must've hoofed it. Flagstaff smiles TIMIDLY at Albuquerque, but DOESN’T ANSW

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Probably west. Flagstaff cocks his head... that would be logical.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Drive slowly, eyes open. Flagstaff bites his lip but doesn’t hit the gas. Albuquer stares for a moment, then faces forward.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: They’re in the back seat, huh? Flagstaff NODS apologetically.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: Just me! STILLWATER pops up in the back seat, pointing Flagstaff’s SHOTGUN at the back of Albuquerque’s neck. Its BARREL has been SAWED OFF.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (glimpses Stillwater, then stares at Flagstaff) You got taken hostage. By an eleven-year- old.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: She's way ahead of where I was at that age.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: Eleven’s the new seventeen! (to Albuquerque) Gun, please.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: (eyes Stillwater’s shotgun) Sawed off the barrel?

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: (nods ) Barely have to aim.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Like you’d ever shoot that th-  54. Before Albuquerque can even finish his sentence, Stillwat IMMEDIATELY, without hesitation, FIRES TWO SHOTGUN BLASTS the window. Then, before Albuquerque’s even recovered fro his flinch, she rapidly EJECTS the SHELLS, slides in two ones, and slaps the GUN closed AGAIN.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Jesus! A little agro!

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: All those violent video games... Albuquerque quickly hands his rifle into the BACK SEAT.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: (to Flagstaff) Drive. Flagstaff drives up the far side of the valley.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
dialogues.text: Now flash your brights. Flagstaff FLASHES the BRIGHTS. Immediately, WICHITA emerg from a CLUSTER of ROCKS, so WELL HIDDEN it’s like she’s emerging from thin air. Albuquerque raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: FLAGSTAFF
dialogues.text: (to Albuquerque, gesturing toward Stillwater) She was hidden even better. (off Albuquerque’s GLARE) ‘Cause she’s smaller. Wichita aims the AK-47 at Flagstaff and opens his door.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: I’m the first to admit. This is a little awkward. Step away from the vehicle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALBUQUERQUE and FLAGSTAFF stand by their duffel bag and roller suitcase, respectively. They stare helplessly as WICHITA and STILLWATER load the last of their own GEAR in the HUMMER, shut the doors, and PULL AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: ALBUQUERQUE
dialogues.text: Assholes. Joke’s on them. Look what I swiped from under the seat!  55. A SELF-SATISFIED Albuquerque holds open the manila ENVELO from earlier, full of COSTUME JEWELRY RINGS. Flagstaff ro his eyes. Albuquerque and Flagstaff watch as their nemese head WEST, literally DRIVING OFF into the SUNSET.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WICHITA and STILLWATER cruise west on the 10 FREEWAY, LAUGHING as they discuss the guys.

dialogues.speaker: WICHITA
dialogues.text: With the muscles and the glasses. And how he sucks in his stomach. I’m guessing high school football trainer. Probably taped a lotta ankles. Smelled like BenGay.

dialogues.speaker: STILLWATER
